SECTION 2 — FULL STATEMENT OF OBJECTIVES (SOO) (~10 pages)
————————————————————————————————
1.1 MISSION CONTEXT
The Department of the Air Force (DAF) operates one of the most complex, globally distributed supply and sustainment infrastructures in the world. Across dozens of Air Logistics Complexes (ALCs), Forward Operating Sites (FOS), and Contractor-Operated facilities, the Air Force relies on a tightly interwoven set of logistics systems, data coordination frameworks, and operational processes to achieve readiness, responsiveness, and mission assurance.
This environment is increasingly challenged by global supply chain instability, adversarial cyber operations targeting logistics systems, degradation in supply chain transparency, and growing system complexity across data sources, enterprise interfaces, and security enclaves. The Air Force must transition from fragmented, reactive monitoring to proactive, integrated, and analytics-driven oversight of logistics activities supporting aircraft availability, munitions readiness, component manufacturing, and distribution timelines.
The Autonomous Logistics Monitoring & Compliance Platform (ALMCP) will provide a unified capability that enhances supply chain intelligence, strengthens cyber posture, and enables senior leadership to take timely, risk-informed actions.

1.2 PURPOSE
The purpose of this effort is to acquire, deploy, secure, and sustain a comprehensive AFLCMC-aligned logistics monitoring and compliance platform capable of:
ingesting and normalizing multi-source logistics data;
automating compliance against NIST, DFARS, and Air Force policies;
providing AI-assisted anomaly detection and risk scoring;
enhancing visibility across supply chain nodes;
supporting IL5 mission systems and enclave requirements; and
enabling readiness-focused decision making.
This SOO articulates what the Air Force seeks to achieve, while the PWS will define how the Contractor shall deliver the required capabilities.

1.3 PROBLEM STATEMENT
Current Air Force logistics oversight faces critical limitations:
Fragmented Legacy Systems
Logistics data is distributed among heterogeneous legacy systems (D035A, IMDS, GO81, SBSS variants, contractor portals, shipping APIs), creating analytic blind spots.
Manual Compliance Overhead
Compliance activities for NIST 800-171, DFARS 7012, and internal AF security controls require substantial manual labor and often lack traceability or standardization.
Inconsistent Data Accuracy and Provenance
Data lineage, quality scoring, validation, and provenance tracking differ across organizations and contract vehicles.
Growing Threat Environment
Adversaries increasingly target logistics nodes, contractor manufacturing facilities, and unclassified-but-sensitive systems supporting readiness.
Limited Predictive Capability
The Air Force lacks automated predictive analytics capable of forecasting supply chain delays, component shortages, vendor vulnerabilities, cyber anomalies, or mission risk.
These deficiencies degrade readiness, lengthen maintenance cycles, and increase operational risk.

1.4 PROGRAM VISION
ALMCP will deliver a transformational capability enabling:
real-time supply chain transparency,
automated compliance workflows,
AI-driven anomaly detection,
secure IL5 processing and auditability, and
enterprise-wide data fusion across Air Force logistics environments.
This capability will serve as the system of record for automated logistics monitoring and compliance across AFMC programs.

1.5 HIGH-LEVEL OBJECTIVES
The Contractor shall provide a solution that achieves:
Objective 1 — Centralized Logistics Oversight
A unified platform aggregating all logistics and supplier activity into a single authoritative dashboard with automated metrics and signals.
Objective 2 — Compliance Automation
Automated control mapping, evidence extraction, and assessment against:
NIST 800-171
NIST 800-53 Rev 5
DFARS 252.204-7012
AF cybersecurity policies
Cloud SRG IL5
Objective 3 — Predictive Intelligence
ML-enhanced risk scoring for:
vendor reliability
part availability
counterfeit indicators
supply chain manipulation
cyber-logistics compromise
Objective 4 — IL5 Aligned Security Posture
A Zero Trust, enclave-compliant system with end-to-end encryption, auditability, and cyber hardening.
Objective 5 — Reduced Analyst Burden
A platform that automates 50–70% of manual tasks, reducing reporting cycles and freeing personnel for operational decision-making.

1.6 SCOPE
The Contractor shall deliver:
system architecture
secure software design
enclave integration
data ingestion + ETL pipelines
analytics layer
compliance engine
dashboards
testing + evaluation
training
IL5 sustainment
full ATO package

1.7 CONSTRAINTS
All data shall remain within AWS GovCloud IL5 boundaries.
No external APIs or commercial AI models shall process Air Force data.
All personnel must be U.S. citizens with appropriate clearance.
All code shall be developed using secure pipelines approved for IL5.

1.8 DESIRED OUTCOMES
The platform shall enable AFLCMC to:
monitor mission-critical logistics in real time;
proactively mitigate supply chain disruptions;
reduce compliance churn;
improve readiness forecasting accuracy;
enhance leadership decision superiority.
2.0 PERFORMANCE WORK STATEMENT (PWS)
2.1 INTRODUCTION
This Performance Work Statement (PWS) defines the tasks, activities, responsibilities, performance standards, and deliverables required for the design, development, integration, testing, accreditation, deployment, and sustainment of the Autonomous Logistics Monitoring & Compliance Platform (ALMCP). The PWS is written in accordance with Air Force Life Cycle Management Center (AFLCMC) policy, standard acquisition practices, and Department of Defense (DoD) guidance.
The Contractor shall furnish all personnel, materials, labor, travel, supervision, equipment, software licenses, secure hosting components, cloud infrastructure, planning artifacts, documentation, testing support, and management oversight necessary to meet the requirements described herein.
The ALMCP capability is essential to ensuring that Air Force logistics and sustainment operations maintain high reliability, traceability, and resilience in the face of evolving strategic competition, hostile cyber operations, supply chain manipulation, and complex vendor ecosystems. The platform shall serve as an enterprise capability supporting program offices, logistics directorates, supply chain analysts, cybersecurity personnel, and readiness decision makers across the Air Force.
The PWS outlines performance requirements for:
Cloud architecture & IL5 infrastructure
Data ingestion & normalization pipelines
AI/ML analytics and anomaly detection
Automated compliance mapping and evidence generation
Platform cybersecurity & Zero Trust alignment
Continuous monitoring & audit traceability
Program management & configuration control
Test and evaluation (T&E) processes
Training, documentation, and sustainment activities
Deliverables and CDRLs
All activities shall be performed in a manner that ensures security, operational continuity, technical accuracy, and full alignment to Air Force mission and compliance requirements.

2.2 SYSTEM OVERVIEW
The ALMCP capability will operate as a multi-layered cloud-native system delivering logistics monitoring, data fusion, predictive analytics, and compliance automation across the Air Force enterprise. The system will include:
Secure data ingestion and ETL pipelines
Storage and data processing layers within IL5 enclaves
An analytics engine incorporating heuristic, rule-based, and AI/ML components
Dashboards and user interfaces tailored to various mission roles
Automated workflows supporting compliance, anomaly detection, and reporting
APIs for integration with Air Force systems, contractor systems, and enterprise identity services
Continuous monitoring sensors and audit logging components
The solution shall be architected to comply with the DoD Cloud Computing Security Requirements Guide (SRG), Air Force Platform One based expectations, Zero Trust reference architecture, and all applicable NIST and DoD cybersecurity frameworks.

2.3 REQUIREMENTS OVERVIEW
The Contractor shall design and deliver the ALMCP solution in alignment with the high-level objectives outlined in the SOO and the technical and operational requirements of this PWS. The requirements described in this document specify the expected performance outcomes of the Contractor. Where ambiguity exists, the Contractor is responsible for seeking clarification from the Government and ensuring compliance with the intent—not merely the literal textual interpretation—of the requirement.
The ALMCP requirements are structured across multiple domains:

2.4 APPLICABLE DOCUMENTS (EXTENDED LIST)
The Contractor shall comply with the latest versions of all documents outlined below, as applicable. The Government may update this list as policies, standards, and frameworks evolve. The Contractor shall continuously monitor for updates and implement changes in accordance with AFLCMC guidance.
2.4.1 Department of Defense (DoD) Documents
DoD Cloud Computing Security Requirements Guide (SRG), Impact Level 5
DoD Instruction 8510.01 — Risk Management Framework (RMF)
DoDM 5200.01 Volumes 1–4 — DoD Information Security Program
DoDI 5000.02 — Operation of the Adaptive Acquisition Framework
DoDI 8500.01 — Cybersecurity
DoDI 8510.01 — RMF for DoD IT
DoD Zero Trust Strategy
DoD Cyber Workforce Framework
2.4.2 Air Force Documents
Air Force Instruction (AFI) 17-101 — Risk Management Framework
AFI 17-130 — Cybersecurity Program Management
AFLCMC Standard Acquisition Management Practices
Air Force DevSecOps Reference Architecture
Platform One Party Bus and Big Bang Documentation
Air Force Zero Trust Reference Architecture
Air Force Supply Chain Integration Guidance
2.4.3 NIST Publications
NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5
NIST SP 800-171 Rev 2
NIST SP 800-172 Enhancements
NIST SP 800-137 — Continuous Monitoring
NIST SP 800-207 — Zero Trust Architecture
NIST SP 800-190 — Container Security Guide
2.4.4 Federal Publications
FedRAMP Moderate Baseline
FIPS 140-3 Cryptographic Module Validation Program
Federal Information Security Modernization Act (FISMA)
Executive Orders 14028 (Improving the Nation’s Cybersecurity)
2.4.5 Contractual and Legal
DFARS 252.204-7012 Safeguarding CDI
DFARS 252.204-7019 Notice of NIST Assessment
DFARS 252.204-7020 NIST Assessment Requirements
DFARS 252.204-7021 CMMC Level 2 Requirements
FAR 52.204-21 Basic Safeguarding of Covered Contractor Info
FAR 52.239-1 Privacy and Security Safeguards
2.4.6 Air Force Logistics Systems & Interfaces
The Contractor shall integrate with, align with, or consider data from:
D035A Repair Data System
IMDS (Integrated Maintenance Data System)
GO81
Defense Logistics Agency (DLA) systems
Contractor-operated manufacturing and tracking systems
Supplier risk databases (GovCloud variants only)
Air Force Identity, Credential, and Access Management (ICAM) services

2.5 GENERAL PERFORMANCE REQUIREMENTS
2.5.1 Contractor Responsibility
The Contractor shall ensure:
All system components meet IL5 security requirements.
All personnel maintain proper clearances.
All development is performed within secure pipelines.
All deliverables meet Air Force quality standards.
All integration points are fully documented.
All operational activities follow AFLCMC security, privacy, and acquisition policy.
2.5.2 Air Force-Furnished Information
The Government will provide:
Access to AF test accounts
Air Force identity services integration documentation
Logistics data schemas
IL5 baseline architecture diagrams
ATO requirements and templates
The Contractor is responsible for safeguarding all AF-furnished information in accordance with RMF and DFARS 7012 requirements.

2.6 BASELINE SYSTEM CHARACTERISTICS
The ALMCP system shall:
process 25,000+ logistics events per hour;
support 1,500+ concurrent authenticated users;
achieve 99.9% uptime excluding approved maintenance windows;
deliver dashboards within 4 seconds;
generate compliance packages within 45 seconds;
handle multi-source data integration with strict schema enforcement;
operate entirely within IL5 boundaries;
utilize Zero Trust principles for all access decisions.
3.0 SYSTEM ARCHITECTURE REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall design, develop, integrate, test, document, and deliver a fully operational, cloud-native system architecture for the Autonomous Logistics Monitoring & Compliance Platform (ALMCP). The architecture shall comply with Air Force, DoD, and Federal cybersecurity and system engineering requirements. The ALMCP architecture shall emphasize modularity, scalability, containerization, fault tolerance, continuous monitoring, and strict adherence to IL5 security controls.
All architectural decisions shall reflect best practices for mission-critical Air Force systems, including high availability, component redundancy, secure enclave segmentation, clear data flows, and robust auditability.

3.1 ARCHITECTURAL PRINCIPLES
The ALMCP system architecture shall be guided by the following principles:
3.1.1 Zero Trust-First Design
Every access attempt—user or system—shall be authenticated, authorized, encrypted, logged, and evaluated using context-based policies. No implicit trust shall exist between components.
3.1.2 Modular Microservice Composition
The architecture shall consist of discrete microservices deployed in orchestration clusters, each performing isolated functions with defined APIs, independent scaling, and separate security contexts.
3.1.3 Cloud Native Implementation
The system shall leverage cloud-native patterns appropriate for IL5 environments, including container orchestration, infrastructure as code, native logging pipelines, secret management, key management, and cloud monitoring.
3.1.4 Redundancy and Fault Tolerance
All mission-critical components, including ingestion pipelines, databases, queues, and UI interfaces, shall be multi-AZ redundant.
3.1.5 Observability
System observability shall encompass metrics, logs, traces, and health indicators. The system shall provide full lifecycle traceability for user actions, data transformations, and system events.
3.1.6 Scalability
The architecture shall support scale-out capabilities to accommodate expanded logistics datasets, new interfaces, increased user load, and growth in Air Force mission operations.

3.2 CLOUD INFRASTRUCTURE REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall deploy all ALMCP components into IL5-authorized AWS GovCloud regions. All system infrastructure shall comply with the DoD Cloud Computing Security Requirements Guide (SRG) and Air Force Platform One hosting requirements.
3.2.1 Virtual Private Cloud Configuration
The ALMCP VPC shall include:
Segmented public, private, data, and enclave subnets
Route tables enabling controlled communication
VPC endpoints for S3, KMS, SQS, and other GovCloud-native services
Network ACLs enforcing workload isolation
No direct connectivity to external or commercial cloud resources
TLS 1.2+ encryption enforced for all internal and external traffic
3.2.2 Compute Architecture
Compute shall be containerized and orchestrated using a DoD-approved platform (e.g., Kubernetes, Platform One Big Bang). Requirements include:
Self-contained microservices
Declarative deployments
Cluster autoscaling
Pod security policies aligned to Zero Trust
Sidecar containers for logging and mTLS enforcement
3.2.3 Storage Architecture
Storage requirements include:
IL5-compliant, encrypted at-rest databases
Data partitioning for CLI-M vs CLI-S
Multi-AZ replication
Automated snapshots and immutable backup policies
Full audit logs retained for 10 years
3.2.4 Networking and Traffic Control
The architecture shall enforce:
Layer-7 WAF filtering
Mutual TLS (mTLS) for service-to-service traffic
IPS/IDS monitoring
Strict segmentation between public UI endpoints and private services
No outbound internet access without explicit AFLCMC approval

3.3 APPLICATION ARCHITECTURE
ALMCP shall be constructed from interoperable services fulfilling ingestion, processing, analytics, compliance, and reporting functions.
3.3.1 Ingestion Services
The system shall include robust ingestion microservices capable of processing:
API feeds
Batch uploads
Legacy system extracts
Contractor-provided CSV/XML files
Streaming sources provided by Air Force systems
Each ingestion action shall:
Validate schema
Apply metadata enrichment
Tag classification level
Log provenance
Trigger transformation workflows
3.3.2 Transformation & ETL Layer
The ETL component must:
Normalize inconsistent data
Enforce DSIS/AF schemas
Apply data quality scoring
Detect data anomalies
Produce lineage metadata for auditability
3.3.3 Data Processing Services
Processing components shall handle:
Business logic execution
AI/ML computations
Compliance rule execution
Risk scoring
Pipeline orchestration
Data processing shall be fully event-driven and resilient to node failures.
3.3.4 Analytics Engine
The analytics engine shall include:
ML anomaly detection
Predictive modeling
Vendor reliability scoring
Disruption forecasting
Counterfeit/material fraud indicators
All models shall be explainable and validated.
3.3.5 Compliance Engine
The compliance module shall:
Map inputs to NIST/DFARS controls
Generate evidence packages
Identify gaps
Populate POA&Ms
Provide dashboards for auditors and PMs
3.3.6 User Interface & UX
The UI shall be:
Intuitive for analysts
Role-based and permission-aware
WCAG accessibility compliant
Optimized for load/performance
Supportive of rapid filtering, searching, exporting, and alerting

3.4 IDENTITY, ACCESS CONTROL, & ZERO TRUST
3.4.1 Identity Providers
The system shall integrate with:
Air Force ICAM
SAML / OIDC authentication
CAC/PIV-based login
Attribute-based access controls (ABAC)
3.4.2 Access Controls
Access shall follow:
Zero Trust decisioning
Attribute-based enforcement
Least privilege principles
Dynamic permission contexts
Examples:
Analysts may view only mission-relevant supply chain data
Contractors may only view customer-restricted datasets
Elevated privileges expire automatically (just-in-time access)
3.4.3 Session Management
The system shall enforce:
Strict session token expiration
Session binding to device/browser
No cross-tab session replication
MFA reauthentication for high-risk actions

3.5 SYSTEM INTEGRATION REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall design and implement integration points for:
AF logistics data systems (IMDS, D035A, GO81, etc.)
Air Force ICAM
GovCloud-native services
Air Force audit pipelines
All integrations must include:
API specifications
Error handling logic
Message signing
Data lineage tracking
Interface control documentation (ICD)
No integration shall introduce inbound/outbound data paths not pre-approved by the Government.

3.6 PERFORMANCE REQUIREMENTS
3.6.1 Throughput
The system shall process 25,000+ logistics events per hour without degradation.
3.6.2 User Concurrency
The system shall support 1,500+ concurrent authenticated users.
3.6.3 Availability
System availability shall be 99.9%, excluding Government-approved maintenance windows.
3.6.4 Response Time
Dashboard load: ≤ 4 seconds
Compliance report generation: ≤ 45 seconds
API response time (P95): ≤ 300 ms
3.6.5 Scalability
The system shall support at least 5× projected growth with minimal architectural refactoring.
4.0 CYBERSECURITY & INFORMATION PROTECTION REQUIREMENTS
Cybersecurity is foundational to all aspects of ALMCP design, development, deployment, and sustainment. The Contractor shall ensure the platform complies with all DoD and Air Force cybersecurity standards, including but not limited to the Risk Management Framework (RMF), Cybersecurity Maturity Model Certification (CMMC), NIST publications, and DoD Zero Trust architecture principles.
All ALMCP components shall be deployed within an Impact Level 5 (IL5) enclave in AWS GovCloud (US) and shall adhere to the security principles outlined in the DoD Cloud Computing Security Requirements Guide (SRG), the Air Force Zero Trust Reference Architecture, and applicable Air Force cybersecurity policy.

4.1 GENERAL CYBERSECURITY REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall:
Implement a cybersecurity program aligned with AFI 17-101, DoDI 8500.01, and NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5.
Provide an end-to-end security architecture demonstrating segmentation, Zero Trust enforcement, encryption, auditability, and full compliance with IL5 hosting constraints.
Protect all Covered Defense Information (CDI) and Controlled Unclassified Information (CUI) processed, stored, or transmitted by ALMCP.
Ensure all personnel hold U.S. citizenship and have background checks appropriate for IL5 operations.
Maintain a continuous cybersecurity posture, including real-time monitoring, alerting, patching, and risk assessment.
The Contractor shall treat cybersecurity as a core mission requirement—not a supporting function.

4.2 RISK MANAGEMENT FRAMEWORK (RMF) REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall complete:
Full RMF package development
System categorization
Control implementation statements
Assessment procedures (NIST SP 800-53A)
POA&M creation and management
Security Assessment Report (SAR) development
ATO package submission
The ALMCP system must achieve and maintain Authority to Operate (ATO) under RMF.
4.2.1 Control Allocation
The Contractor shall:
Implement contractor-owned and contractor-operated controls
Document inheritance from the cloud provider (AWS GovCloud IL5)
Document inheritance from Air Force enterprise services (ICAM, SIEM, etc.)
Provide detailed shared responsibility matrices
Control gaps shall be documented immediately and addressed per Government direction.

4.3 CLOUD SRG IL5 REQUIREMENTS
ALMCP must comply with every technical, operational, and management control outlined in the DoD Cloud Computing SRG for IL5 workloads.
Mandatory IL5 requirements include:
Enclave segmentation
Encrypted data flows (TLS 1.2 or higher)
Customer-managed encryption keys (KMS)
Multi-AZ redundancy
Strict IAM policies
Continuous monitoring feeds to Air Force SIEM
No external or commercial service integration without Government approval
Prohibited actions (MANDATORY):
No processing of Air Force data on external AI/LLM providers
No downloading containers from public registries in production
No outbound internet access from IL5 nodes
No storing backup data outside GovCloud IL5 boundaries
Failure to meet IL5 technical requirements constitutes a critical deficiency.

4.4 ZERO TRUST ARCHITECTURE REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall design ALMCP in full alignment with the DoD Zero Trust Strategy and Air Force Zero Trust Reference Architecture.
Zero Trust capabilities shall include:
Identity Pillar:
CAC/PIV + OIDC/SAML integration
ABAC policy enforcement
Device posture checking (when applicable)
Network Pillar:
Micro-segmentation
mTLS at all service boundaries
WAF + IPS/IDS
Application Pillar:
Secure coding, dependency scanning, SBOM integrity
Automated injection of “deny-by-default” API gateway rules
Data Pillar:
Attribute-based data access constraints
Classification tagging at ingestion
End-to-end encryption
Analytics Pillar:
Real-time behavior and anomaly detection
Automated policy adjustment triggers
Automation Pillar:
Policy-as-code
Automated compliance reporting
Infrastructure-as-code with signed deployments
The Contractor shall provide a Zero Trust enforcement diagram showing all trust decisions, telemetry, and control points.

4.5 DATA PROTECTION & ENCRYPTION
4.5.1 Data in Transit
All traffic (internal and external) shall be encrypted using:
TLS 1.2+
Mutual TLS (mTLS) for service-to-service communication
FIPS 140-3 validated libraries only
4.5.2 Data at Rest
All stored data (structured, semi-structured, and unstructured) shall:
Be encrypted using AES-256 or stronger
Utilize customer-managed KMS keys
Include key rotation processes
Utilize separate volumes for CLI-M and CLI-S
Maintain full auditability of all decryption events
4.5.3 Sensitive Data Requirements
Examples of data requiring heightened protections:
Logistics disruption indicators
Vendor reliability data
Contractual risk and compliance evidence
Classified Logistics Information – Sensitive (CLI-S)
Proprietary manufacturing datasets
Access to these data types must be governed by strict ABAC rules.

4.6 AUDIT & LOGGING REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall implement full-spectrum logging and audit mechanisms including:
Log Categories Required:
Authentication attempts
API calls
Data ingestion events
Data transformations
Data access events
Permission escalations
Failed authorization attempts
System configuration changes
Administrative actions
Deployment pipeline events
AI/ML model outputs and decisions
Retention Requirements:
10 years minimum for IL5 audit logs
Logs must be immutable and tamper-evident
Logs must be forwarded to Air Force SIEM
Hidden Mandatory Requirement:
All logs containing mission-sensitive metadata must be classified at least CLI-M, with some logs automatically escalating to CLI-S based on content.
The system must detect such escalations automatically.

4.7 SECURITY INCIDENT RESPONSE
The Contractor shall develop and maintain:
Incident Response Plan (IRP)
Cybersecurity SOPs
Escalation workflows
Contact rosters
Response time SLAs
The Contractor shall:
Report incidents to the Government within 1 hour
Retain all evidence in IL5 storage
Support forensic analysis
Implement lessons learned within 30 days
All incidents involving CDI or CLI-S data shall be treated as severity-1 events.

4.8 SECURE SOFTWARE DEVELOPMENT (DevSecOps)
The Contractor shall implement AFLCMC-approved DevSecOps pipelines including:
Required Tooling & Controls:
Static Application Security Testing (SAST)
Dynamic Application Security Testing (DAST)
Software Composition Analysis (SCA)
Container vulnerability scanning
IaC scanning (Terraform, Helm, etc.)
Secrets scanning
Dependency integrity verification (cryptographic signing)
SBOM Requirements:
The Contractor shall produce:
SBOMs for all microservices
SBOMs for container images
SBOMs for infrastructure-as-code repos
All SBOMs must be exportable to Government systems.
Code Governance Requirements:
Mandatory peer review
Signed commits only
No third-party packages from unapproved repos
No public container images in production

4.9 MALWARE PROTECTION & SUPPLY CHAIN DEFENSE
The ALMCP system shall:
Scan all incoming files
Validate all dependencies
Implement anti-tamper controls
Monitor supply chain integrity
Detect anomalies in software behavior
Apply runtime application self-protection (RASP) where applicable
The Contractor shall maintain an internal supply chain risk register.

4.10 CONTINUOUS MONITORING
Continuous monitoring (CONMON) shall include:
Automated control checks
Vulnerability scanning
Runtime security analytics
SIEM integration
Configuration drift detection
Compliance dashboard reporting
Zero Trust posture metrics
The Contractor shall provide weekly dashboards and monthly reports.
5.0 DATA MANAGEMENT & DATA GOVERNANCE REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall implement a comprehensive data management, governance, and stewardship framework for all data processed, stored, transmitted, or generated by the Autonomous Logistics Monitoring & Compliance Platform (ALMCP). This framework shall ensure accuracy, consistency, reliability, provenance, and protection of logistics data across the Air Force enterprise.
The data management solution shall comply with all applicable Air Force, DoD, and Federal laws, including FISMA, DFARS, NIST SP 800-series publications, and Air Force metadata standards.

5.1 DATA MANAGEMENT STRATEGY
The Contractor shall develop and maintain a Data Management Strategy addressing:
Data sources and ingestion pathways
Data classification & handling rules
Quality assurance and scoring
Metadata tagging, versioning, and cataloging
Data retention and disposition policies
Data normalization and standardization schemas
Lineage tracking across processing stages
Governance roles and responsibilities
Constraints required for IL5 data protection
The strategy shall be submitted as a CDRL deliverable and updated baseline at Government direction.

5.2 DATA CLASSIFICATION & HANDLING
5.2.1 Required Classification Schema
All data shall be automatically tagged as one of the following:
CLI-S — Classified Logistics Information – Sensitive
CLI-M — Mission-sensitive logistics information with restricted access
CLI-P — Public or unrestricted logistics data
Classification shall be determined at ingestion based on:
Data type
Originating source system
Semantic content
Security controls required by AF policy
5.2.2 Automated Classification Rules
The Contractor shall implement automated classification logic that:
Identifies sensitive fields (e.g., component status, vulnerability indicators)
Flags data containing potential supply chain threats
Performs keyword and pattern-based detection
Applies classifiers using ML where appropriate
Escalates classification when uncertainty exists
5.2.3 Manual Overrides
Authorized Air Force personnel may manually adjust classification levels.
All overrides shall be:
Logged
Audited
Justified with a written rationale
Reviewed quarterly

5.3 DATA INGESTION REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall implement ingestion pipelines capable of processing:
Real-time streaming data
Batch files from legacy systems
API-based payloads
Vendor-supplied datasets
Contractor-controlled manufacturing data extracts
Air Force logistics messages (XML, JSON, CSV, custom formats)
All ingestion actions shall:
Validate file integrity
Enforce schema rules
Apply metadata tagging
Detect anomalies
Score data quality
Generate lineage tracking records
Encrypt and store data appropriately
No ingestion workflow may bypass security controls or classification routines.

5.4 DATA QUALITY REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall implement a Data Quality Framework including:
5.4.1 Quality Dimensions
Each ingested dataset shall be scored for:
Accuracy
Completeness
Timeliness
Consistency
Uniqueness
Validity
5.4.2 Threshold Enforcement
If datasets fall below quality thresholds:
They must be quarantined
Annotated with the failure reason
Reported to AF users
Reprocessed or rejected based on business rules
5.4.3 Continuous Quality Monitoring
The system shall produce:
Daily quality dashboards
Trend analysis
Alerts when deterioration is detected
Machine-learning-enhanced quality heuristics

5.5 METADATA REQUIREMENTS
Metadata management is critical for understanding data provenance, lineage, classification, and transformation history.
5.5.1 Metadata Categories
ALMCP must store:
Structural metadata (schema, format, types)
Descriptive metadata (origin, owner, timestamps)
Administrative metadata (permissions, retention)
Security metadata (classification, access level)
Operational metadata (processing duration, errors)
Semantic metadata (tags, topics, inferred attributes)
5.5.2 Metadata Storage
Metadata shall:
Be immutable once recorded
Reside in IL5-approved storage
Maintain multi-AZ redundancy
Include hash-based integrity proofs
5.5.3 Metadata Exposure
Metadata shall be:
Searchable
Queryable
Exportable
Usable for audit and compliance reporting

5.6 DATA LINEAGE REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall implement full end-to-end lineage tracking covering:
Data ingestion events
Transformations
Rule applications
AI/ML scoring
User manipulations
Compliance tagging
Export actions
Lineage must be visualized in the UI and exportable for audits.
5.6.1 Immutable Lineage Records
All lineage entries shall be:
Cryptographically signed
Tamper-evident
Linked to original ingestion events
Retained for 10 years minimum
5.6.2 Provenance Chains
Provenance chains must show:
Original source system
All intermediaries
Transformation history
Classification decisions
Access history

5.7 DATA RETENTION & DISPOSITION
The Contractor shall implement retention policies consistent with Air Force Records Management requirements.
5.7.1 Retention Timelines
Compliance artifacts: 10 years
Audit logs: 10 years
Operational logistics data: 7–10 years unless otherwise directed
Temporary files: ≤ 24 hours unless needed for mission tasks
5.7.2 Disposition Rules
When data is no longer required:
Secure deletion must follow DoD 5220.22-M (or successor)
Cryptographic erasure acceptable for IL5 workloads
Records of disposition must be logged and auditable

5.8 DATA EXPORT & SHARING
5.8.1 Allowed Export Formats
PDF
JSON
CSV
XML
AF-approved custom formats
5.8.2 Export Controls
All export actions shall:
Enforce classification controls
Validate recipient permissions
Log every export operation
Apply watermarking for traceability
Be restricted for CLI-S datasets unless approved
No data may be exported outside the IL5 boundary.
Hidden Mandatory Requirement:
Even internal Air Force exports must undergo a classification re-check prior to release.

5.9 DATA ACCESS & AUTHORIZATION
Access shall be:
Governed by ABAC
Context-aware
Logged and auditable
Enforced through Zero Trust policy engines
5.9.1 Sensitive Data Protections
Access to:
Vendor risk insights
Disruption predictions
Compliance evidence
Material vulnerability indicators
must require elevated privileges and explicit approval chains.

5.10 DATA LOSS PREVENTION (DLP)
The system shall:
Monitor for unauthorized exfiltration
Detect unusual query patterns
Prevent bulk downloads of CLI-M/CLI-S
Apply content scanning to outbound exports
Enforce anomaly-based DLP policies
Incidents shall be automatically escalated to severity level 2 or higher.
6.0 COMPLIANCE AUTOMATION REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall design, implement, and sustain a fully automated compliance capability that aligns with Air Force, DoD, and Federal cybersecurity and logistics oversight requirements. The ALMCP shall significantly reduce the compliance burden on analysts, PMs, auditors, and cybersecurity personnel by automating evidence collection, mapping controls to observed events, identifying gaps, and generating actionable compliance insights.
The compliance automation subsystem is a mission-critical capability and shall be architected with reliability, auditability, classification awareness, and traceability as mandatory requirements.

6.1 COMPLIANCE FRAMEWORK SUPPORT
The system shall support automated compliance mapping against the following frameworks:
6.1.1 Cybersecurity Frameworks
NIST SP 800-171 Rev 2
NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5
NIST SP 800-53A Assessment Procedures
NIST SP 800-207 Zero Trust
NIST SP 800-137 Continuous Monitoring
6.1.2 DoD / Air Force Requirements
DoD SRG IL5
DoDI 8500.01 Cybersecurity
DoDI 8510.01 RMF for DoD IT
DFARS 252.204-7012
DFARS 252.204-7019
DFARS 252.204-7020
DFARS 252.204-7021 (CMMC Level 2)
Air Force Cybersecurity Policies and Supplements
6.1.3 Contract & Vendor Compliance
Supplier security posture assessments
Vendor non-conformance detection
Subcontractor compliance indicators
The Contractor shall maintain up-to-date mappings when frameworks change.

6.2 AUTOMATED CONTROL MAPPING
The system shall automatically:
Evaluate evidence from logs, configurations, data flows, and user actions.
Map platform telemetry to RMF/NIST/DFARS controls.
Generate real-time compliance scores.
Flag deviations or gaps requiring action.
Track compliance over time through dashboards and periodic summaries.
6.2.1 Evidence Collection Requirements
Evidence shall be:
Automatically gathered from system events
Tagged with lineage metadata
Classified based on content
Organized into exportable evidence bundles
Linked to specific controls and sub-controls
6.2.2 Assessment Logic Engine
The Contractor shall implement an assessment engine capable of:
Rule-based control evaluation
Machine-learning-assisted compliance predictions
Behavioral compliance drift detection
Automatic remediation recommendations
Compliance findings shall trigger automated alerts.

6.3 COMPLIANCE REPORT GENERATION
The system shall generate:
6.3.1 Standard Reports
RMF Control Status Report
POA&M Summary
DFARS 7012 Incident Reporting Status
NIST 800-171 Assessment Report (basic, medium, high)
CMMC Level 2 Evidence Package
6.3.2 Logistics-Specific Reports
Supply Chain Vulnerability Exposure
Vendor Trustworthiness Scorecard
Disruption Risk Assessment
Counterfeit Detection Summary
6.3.3 Audit Support Reports
Control-by-control evidence mapping
Timestamped log extracts
Access control verification reports
Encryption and key rotation summary
Configuration baseline deltas
All reports must be:
Exportable
Classified appropriately
Watermarked
Fully traceable to source data

6.4 POA&M (PLAN OF ACTION & MILESTONES) AUTOMATION
The Contractor shall implement a fully automated POA&M management subsystem.
6.4.1 POA&M Generation
When compliance gaps are detected, the system shall automatically:
Create POA&M entries
Assign severity levels
Recommend remediation steps
Assign stakeholders
Calculate estimated completion timelines
6.4.2 POA&M Tracking
Tracking shall include:
Status updates
Evidence of remediation
Risk scoring
Automated notifications
Audit-ready exports
6.4.3 POA&M Governance
The system must support:
Multi-role workflows
Approval chains
Digital signature requirements
Internal Air Force reviews

6.5 SELF-ASSESSMENT & CONTROL VALIDATION
The Contractor shall provide interfaces allowing:
Self-assessment forms
Automated validation
Re-scoring of controls
Analyst input overrides
Audit attachments
The system shall prevent analysts from approving a control if contradictory evidence exists.

6.6 CONTINUOUS COMPLIANCE MONITORING (CONMON)
ALMCP shall automatically perform continuous monitoring aligned to NIST SP 800-137.
6.6.1 Mandatory Monitoring Dimensions
Configuration changes
Privileged access
Ingestion anomalies
Encryption compliance
Key rotation compliance
Audit log completeness
Data classification drift
AI/ML model behavior anomalies
Network segmentation health
Identity and access anomalies
6.6.2 Monitoring Frequency
Real-time for high-impact events
Hourly for configuration checks
Daily for control scoring
Weekly for compliance summaries
Monthly for risk posture reviews

6.7 ALERTING & NOTIFICATION REQUIREMENTS
The system shall generate alerts based on:
6.7.1 Compliance Alerts
Control deviation
Unauthorized access
Failed control checks
Policy violations
Security misconfigurations
6.7.2 Operations Alerts
Ingestion failures
Data quality degradation
Workflow failures
API errors
Unusual processing latencies
6.7.3 Threat Alerts
AI-detected anomalies
Behavioral deviations
Supply chain manipulation indicators
Counterfeit material signals
Vendor risk escalation
Alerts must be:
Routed to authorized personnel
Tracked until closure
Stored for audit

6.8 COMPLIANCE DASHBOARDS
The system shall provide:
6.8.1 Role-Based Dashboards
Program managers
Analysts
Cybersecurity personnel
Auditors
Leadership
6.8.2 Required Views
Overall compliance score
Framework-specific compliance
Control-level detail
POA&M activity
Risk exposure over time
Zero Trust posture indicators
Dashboards shall update in near real time.

6.9 EXPORT REQUIREMENTS
Compliance data must be exportable as:
PDF
JSON
CSV
XML
Evidence bundles
Exports shall:
Respect classification rules
Include provenance metadata
Identify controls affected
Provide timestamped snapshots

6.10 COMPLIANCE DRIFT DETECTION
The system shall detect:
Gradual degradation in compliance
Policy misalignments

New risk introduced by vendor systems

Upon detection:
Alerts must be triggered
POA&M entries created
Dashboards updated
Government notified
7.0 SYSTEM INTEGRATION REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall design, develop, document, implement, test, and sustain all integration interfaces necessary for the ALMCP to interoperate with Air Force enterprise systems, logistics systems, identity services, cloud-native components, and authorized contractor systems. Integration is essential to ensuring accuracy, timeliness, and relevance of logistics monitoring and compliance activities.
All integrations must be secure, auditable, version-controlled, and aligned with IL5 enclave security constraints.

7.1 INTEGRATION PRINCIPLES
The Contractor shall follow the principles below when designing integration components:
7.1.1 Least Privilege Data Exchange
Interfaces must request and provide only the minimum data necessary for mission execution.
7.1.2 Zero Trust Enforcement
Each interface shall:
Authenticate the originating source
Authorize the request based on ABAC policy
Encrypt the payload
Log all access events
Apply dynamic policy checks
7.1.3 Deterministic, Documented Interfaces
Every integration must have:
An Interface Control Document (ICD)
Versioning strategy
Error-handling workflow
Validation logic
Logging and traceability
7.1.4 No Implicit Trust
No system—internal or external—shall be assumed trustworthy without verification (identity, device posture, encryption, attributes).

7.2 AIR FORCE ENTERPRISE SYSTEM INTEGRATION
The ALMCP shall integrate with the following AF systems, adhering to data sharing constraints and approved AFLCMC protocols:
7.2.1 IMDS (Integrated Maintenance Data System)
Data to be ingested from IMDS may include:
Aircraft maintenance events
Part replacement logs
Depot scheduling data
Work unit code updates
The Contractor shall provide mapping tables aligning IMDS data to ALMCP schemas.
7.2.2 D035A Repair Data System
The system shall support ingestion and processing of:
Component repair status
Tail-number-specific logistics metadata
Repair cycle times
Maintenance action codes
7.2.3 GO81 System
Integrate GO81 data for:
Sortie generation operations
Aviation maintenance workflows
Wing-level logistics indicators
7.2.4 DLA (Defense Logistics Agency) Interfaces
The Contractor shall integrate allowed DLA datasets, including:
Material availability
Vendor history
Procurement status
National stock number (NSN) metadata
Only IL5-certified extracts may be ingested.
7.2.5 Air Force ICAM (Identity, Credential, & Access Management)
The ALMCP shall use ICAM for:
Authentication
Attribute-based authorization
Group/role sync
Revocation management
CAC/PIV must be supported natively.

7.3 CONTRACTOR SYSTEMS INTEGRATION
The Contractor shall integrate with authorized vendor systems that support manufacturing, repair, shipping, or supply chain visibility components.
Requirements include:
Secure API ingestion
Schema validation
Provenance tagging
Classification enforcement
Dual-party audit logs
Contractual access restrictions
Data from contractor systems must undergo heightened scrutiny due to supply chain risk.

7.4 CLOUD-NATIVE INTEGRATIONS
The ALMCP system shall integrate with AWS GovCloud IL5 services, including but not limited to:
7.4.1 AWS Lambda (Restricted Use)
Permitted for:
Controlled transformation jobs
Supplemental automation
IL5-compliant event processing
Not permitted for:
Persistent workloads
Unreviewed code execution
7.4.2 AWS KMS (Key Management Service)
Used for:
Encryption key storage
Role-based decryption controls
Automatic key rotation
Must support customer-managed keys.
7.4.3 AWS S3 (IL5 Buckets)
Used for:
Encrypted artifact storage
Evidence bundles
Metadata catalogs
Backup encryption
7.4.4 AWS SQS / SNS
Used for:
Event-driven ingestion pipelines
Guaranteed message delivery
Inter-service coordination
7.4.5 AWS RDS / Aurora PostgreSQL
Requirements:
Multi-AZ redundancy
IL5 encryption compliance
Structured data storage
Transactional logging
Version pinning

7.5 API-GATEWAY REQUIREMENTS
All ALMCP APIs shall be exposed through a secure API gateway implementing:
OAuth2 / OIDC
JWT signing
Dynamic ABAC enforcement
IP filtering
TLS 1.2+ termination
Rate limiting and throttling
Query validation
Schema validation
Payload scanning
APIs must include:
Versioning (v1, v2…)
OpenAPI/Swagger documentation
Developer onboarding guidance
Error code taxonomy
No public APIs may be exposed.

7.6 EVENT-DRIVEN ARCHITECTURE INTEGRATION
The system shall support event-driven architectures (EDA) for:
Logistics status changes
Vendor risk updates
Data quality events
ML scoring tasks
Compliance drift detection
Event Requirements:
Events must be immutable
Events must contain provenance metadata
Subscribers must validate event signatures
Event payloads must not exceed classification limits
All events must be auditable.

7.7 INTERFACE CONTROL DOCUMENTS (ICDs)
The Contractor shall provide ICDs covering:
Interface purpose
Message schemas
Permitted operations
Retention & audit rules
Error-handling logic
Security protocols
Version control mechanisms
Testing & validation procedures
Each ICD shall be a Government-approved CDRL.

7.8 DATA TRANSFORMATION AND NORMALIZATION
All integrated systems produce heterogeneous data types.
The Contractor shall ensure:
Unified schema mapping
Attribute normalization
Timestamp synchronization
NSN and part-number reconciliation
Unit-of-measure conversions
Classification tagging
Metadata enrichment
The ALMCP shall support cross-system correlation at scale.

7.9 ERROR HANDLING & RESILIENCY
Integration workflows must handle:
Partial failures
Retries with backoff
Poison message detection
Queue dead-lettering
Schema mismatch recoveries
Source system downtime
Network throttling
Unexpected classification mismatches
All failures shall create automated alerts and dashboard entries.

7.10 INTEGRATION TESTING REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall perform:
7.10.1 Unit Testing
Test each integration component in isolation.
7.10.2 Interface Testing
Validate end-to-end data flows between AF systems and ALMCP.
7.10.3 Security Testing
Test:
API gateway enforcement
IAM permissions
Data classification
Encryption policies
7.10.4 Load & Stress Testing
Simulate:
Peak ingestion rates
High concurrency
Rapid-fire API access
7.10.5 Mock System Simulations
When AF systems cannot be accessed for testing, the Contractor shall build mock environments replicating schema and behavior.
8.0 TEST & EVALUATION (T&E) REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall conduct comprehensive Test & Evaluation (T&E) activities to validate that all ALMCP components meet performance, security, interoperability, and functional requirements. T&E activities shall align with:
Air Force Life Cycle Management Center (AFLCMC) guidance
AFMC Digital Transformation Testing Practices
DoD Instruction 5000.89 — T&E Management
Air Force DevSecOps test pipelines
RMF validation and ATO requirements
The Contractor shall develop, maintain, and execute a Test & Evaluation Master Plan (TEMP), and shall provide all test procedures, test data, test tools, test reports, and validation results as required by this PWS.

8.1 TEST & EVALUATION MASTER PLAN (TEMP)
The Contractor shall develop a Government-approved TEMP addressing:
Test objectives
Scope and limitations
Test environment configuration
Test resources and data sets
Test roles & responsibilities
Evaluation criteria
Test schedule aligned with IMS
Entrance and exit criteria
Traceability to requirements
Cybersecurity test components
A draft TEMP is due within 60 days after contract award.

8.2 TEST ENVIRONMENTS
The Contractor shall establish, configure, and maintain distinct test environments in IL5:
8.2.1 Development Environment
Used for:
Initial coding
Unit testing
Developer QA
Feature prototyping
8.2.2 Integration Test Environment
Used for:
API validation
Data ingestion tests
End-to-end (E2E) workflows
Initial performance evaluations
8.2.3 Security Test Environment
Used for:
Vulnerability scanning
Penetration testing
RMF control validation
Zero Trust enforcement testing
8.2.4 Pre-Production Environment
Used for:
Final acceptance testing
ATO readiness validation
High-load operational simulation
8.2.5 Production Environment
Government-managed; Contractor must support cutover and post-cutover stabilization.
Each environment shall be segregated, with no unauthorized data flow between them.

8.3 TEST TYPES & REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall perform the following test categories:

8.3.1 UNIT TESTING
Unit testing shall:
Cover ≥ 85% of application logic
Validate microservices in isolation
Verify business rules
Confirm classification tagging
Detect schema mismatches early
Unit test results shall be included in CI/CD pipelines.

8.3.2 INTEGRATION TESTING
Integration testing shall validate:
Ingestion from all AF and contractor systems
Schema conformity
Data flow continuity
Zero Trust policy enforcement
Resilience to disconnects and retries
Event-driven pipeline integrity
The Contractor shall submit Integration Test Reports after each major release.

8.3.3 END-TO-END (E2E) TESTING
End-to-end tests shall validate:
Full system workflows
Data ingestion → processing → analytics → reporting
User authentication & ABAC enforcement
Data export validation
Compliance automation workflows
Dashboards and UI flows
Error-handling logic
E2E tests must reflect real operational scenarios.

8.3.4 PERFORMANCE & LOAD TESTING
Performance testing shall include:
8.3.4.1 Throughput Testing
Validate processing of 25,000+ logistics events per hour.
8.3.4.2 Concurrency Testing
Validate the system’s ability to support 1,500+ concurrent users.
8.3.4.3 Stress Testing
Determine upper limits for ingestion, processing, and analytics loads.
8.3.4.4 Latency Testing
Confirm:
Dashboard load ≤ 4 seconds
Compliance report generation ≤ 45 seconds
API response times (P95) ≤ 300 ms
Performance issues shall trigger remediation plans.

8.3.5 SECURITY TESTING
Security testing is mandatory and shall include:
8.3.5.1 Static Application Security Testing (SAST)
Scan source code for vulnerabilities.
8.3.5.2 Dynamic Application Security Testing (DAST)
Evaluate runtime behavior for vulnerabilities.
8.3.5.3 Penetration Testing
Conduct IL5-authorized penetration tests on:
APIs
Microservices
Databases
Kubernetes clusters
Networking & ingress controllers
8.3.5.4 Zero Trust Validation
Validate that the system:
Does not allow implicit trust
Enforces ABAC
Blocks unauthorized lateral movement
Logs all access attempts
8.3.5.5 Supply Chain Security Testing
Verify:
SBOM accuracy
Dependency integrity
Container hardening
8.3.5.6 RMF Controls Testing
Each control implementation statement shall be validated against SP 800-53A assessment procedures.

8.3.6 USABILITY TESTING
The system shall undergo UX/UI testing to ensure:
Intuitive workflows
Analyst-centered design
Low cognitive load
Accessibility compliance (WCAG 2.1 AA)
Adequate error messaging
Findings shall be incorporated into future releases.

8.3.7 FAILOVER & DISASTER RECOVERY TESTING
The Contractor shall validate:
8.3.7.1 Failover Testing
Multi-AZ redundancy
Automatic failover operations
Data preservation across node failures
8.3.7.2 Disaster Recovery Testing
Conduct annual DR exercises covering:
Region disruption
Database outage
Storage loss scenarios
KMS key failure simulation
Recovery Time Objective (RTO) shall be ≤ 60 minutes.
Recovery Point Objective (RPO) shall be ≤ 15 minutes.

8.3.8 CONTINUITY OF OPERATIONS (COOP) TESTING
The Contractor shall support Government COOP validation activities, ensuring ALMCP remains available during:
System degradation
Loss of external dependencies
Partial or full network outages
Personnel constraints

8.4 TEST DATA MANAGEMENT
The Contractor shall provide and classify all test data, ensuring:
No live Air Force production data is used without approval
Synthetic test data covers edge cases
Classified test data remains within IL5 boundaries
Test data is not accessible outside T&E environments
Each dataset must include:
Schema documentation
Security classification
Intended test scenario usage

8.5 T&E REPORTING REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall deliver:
8.5.1 Test Execution Logs
Detailed logs for each test case, including:
Inputs
Expected outputs
Actual outputs
Pass/fail indicators
Evidence artifacts
8.5.2 Test Reports
Reports shall include:
Summary of tests performed
Failures and remediation actions
Performance metrics
Security findings
Compliance validation results
8.5.3 ATO Readiness Summary
A consolidated evaluation demonstrating readiness for:
RMF assessment
Security Control Assessor (SCA) review
Government ATO decision

8.6 GOVERNMENT WITNESS & PARTICIPATION
The Government reserves the right to:
Witness any Contractor-led test
Request re-test of any failed or borderline result
Request test data and artifacts
Request additional test cases
The Contractor shall accommodate Government observers without additional cost.
9.0 DEPLOYMENT, CUTOVER & TRANSITION REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall plan, coordinate, execute, validate, and support the deployment of the Autonomous Logistics Monitoring & Compliance Platform (ALMCP) into IL5 production environments. Deployment shall occur in a controlled, secure, traceable, and fully auditable manner, following Air Force DevSecOps and AFLCMC deployment best practices.
Deployment activities must ensure zero unplanned mission degradation, data loss, or operational disruption of any Air Force stakeholders or interfacing systems.
All deployment tasks must be traceable to the Integrated Master Schedule (IMS), reviewed during program reviews, and reported in Government status briefings.

9.1 DEPLOYMENT STRATEGY
The Contractor shall develop a Government-approved Deployment Strategy addressing:
Deployment phases
Environment readiness requirements
Data migration needs
Cutover criteria
Security controls activation
Rollback and failback procedures
Stakeholder approval workflows
Dependency readiness validation
Schedule synchronization across AF organizations
The Deployment Strategy shall be delivered as a CDRL within 60 days.

9.2 PRE-DEPLOYMENT ACTIVITIES
Before deployment, the Contractor shall ensure:
9.2.1 Environment Readiness
All IL5 infrastructure is validated
Network segmentation is tested
Access controls and IAM roles are confirmed
Logging and SIEM forwarding are active
Configuration baselines are documented
9.2.2 Government Acceptance Testing
Pre-deployment go/no-go decisions shall require:
Integration testing completion
E2E workflow validation
Security scanning passed
PEN test findings resolved or mitigated
ATO pre-approval review
All defects triaged and addressed
9.2.3 Data Migration Validation
The Contractor shall:
Identify datasets requiring migration
Validate schema consistency
Perform dry-run migrations
Validate classification tagging
Document and mitigate migration risks
Under no circumstances may the Contractor migrate unvalidated data into IL5 production.
9.2.4 User Access Preparation
The Contractor shall:
Prepare user roles and ABAC attributes
Validate account provisioning
Ensure access policies align to Zero Trust
Provide Government with pre-deployment identity mapping

9.3 DEPLOYMENT PHASES
Deployment shall follow a controlled, multi-phase process.
9.3.1 Phase 1 — Initial Production Stand-Up
Stand-up includes:
Provisioning IL5 production VPC
Deploying container clusters
Establishing production databases and storage
Activating Zero Trust enforcement
Configuring load balancers and WAF rules
All components must undergo configuration validation.

9.3.2 Phase 2 — Incremental Feature Deployment
Features shall be deployed incrementally to:
Minimize risk
Validate functionality in controlled stages
Allow rollback at microservice granularity
Maintain continuous operational availability
Each release shall include:
Release notes
Version control identifiers
Security compliance reports
Test summaries
Configuration manifests
No “big bang” releases are authorized unless explicitly approved.

9.3.3 Phase 3 — Data Migration
The Contractor shall:
Perform migration using secure, IL5-compliant pathways
Verify all data integrity checks
Validate classification tags
Re-run lineage metadata creation
Execute automated data quality scoring
Reconcile data discrepancies with source system owners
Migration failure shall trigger automatic rollback.

9.3.4 Phase 4 — Parallel Operations
The Contractor shall support:
Side-by-side operation of old and new systems
Validation of data consistency
Monitoring of operational KPIs
Stakeholder feedback loops
Issue tracking and rapid hotfix deployment
Parallel operations shall last as long as Government directs.

9.3.5 Phase 5 — Cutover to ALMCP
Cutover shall occur only after:
Government approval
ATO authorization
Data validation completion
Functional verification
Security posture verification
Cutover activities include:
Redirecting feeds to ALMCP
Enabling production routing rules
Updating dashboards and APIs
Freezing legacy system ingestion
Activating Government notification channels
Government retains final approval authority.

9.3.6 Phase 6 — Post-Cutover Stabilization
The Contractor shall:
Monitor performance for 90 days
Provide daily/weekly stabilization reports
Respond to issues within required SLAs
Adjust configuration baselines
Optimize ingestion and analytics workflows
Validate compliance automation accuracy
Any mission-impacting issues shall require immmediate escalation.

9.4 ROLLBACK & FAILBACK REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall implement rollback procedures enabling safe restoration of prior configurations or dataset versions.
Mandatory rollback elements:
Snapshot-based restoration
Database point-in-time recovery
Rollback-to-version pipeline capability
Restoration of security policies
Full audit trail of actions taken
Rollback plans must be tested BEFORE production deployment.
Failback procedures shall mirror cutover requirements.

9.5 TRANSITION TO SUSTAINMENT
The Contractor shall deliver all materials, documentation, and training required to transition the ALMCP system into long-term sustainment.
Transition Deliverables include:
As-built architecture diagrams
Administrator guides
SOPs for ingestion, analytics, compliance, and monitoring
Troubleshooting guides
Configuration management artifacts
User role definitions
Zero Trust policy documentation
RMF evidence packages
The Contractor shall support Government sustainment personnel for the first 12 months post-cutover.

9.6 KNOWLEDGE TRANSFER REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall conduct knowledge transfer through:
Formal instructor-led training sessions
Technical deep dives on each subsystem
Hands-on workshops for administrators and cyber teams
Deployment and rollback walk-throughs
Tooling and dashboard usage training
Training must be repeatable, recorded, and exportable.

9.7 CONTINUITY OF OPERATIONS (COOP) PREPARATION
Deployment must include:
Validation of COOP failover mechanisms
IL5 region redundancy checks
Automated health check verification
Failover test exercises
Government-accessible COOP dashboards
COOP activation shall NOT require Contractor presence.

9.8 DEPLOYMENT METRICS & SUCCESS CRITERIA
Deployment is considered successful when:
All features perform at IL5 readiness
Security controls pass Government validation
Performance meets SLA thresholds
No unplanned downtime occurs
All data migrations pass accuracy thresholds (≥99.95%)
Users report successful access and workflow completion
Zero Trust enforcement is validated
All logs, events, and metrics flow to AF SIEM
Government retains the right to delay acceptance until all conditions are met.

Role-based access
Instructor tools for user progress tracking
Resettable training scenarios
Training data must not expose classified or sensitive real-world logistics data.

10.6 TRAINING MATERIALS
Training materials shall include:
Instructor slide decks
Student workbooks
Step-by-step hands-on labs
Administrator handbooks
Video recordings
Online reference materials
Knowledge base articles
All materials must be:
Version-controlled
Aligned with system updates
Approved by the Government
Provided in IL5-compliant formats

10.7 TRAINING DELIVERY SCHEDULE
The Contractor shall deliver initial training prior to Initial Operational Capability (IOC):
10.7.1 Training Waves
Wave 1: Administrator + Cyber
Wave 2: Analyst + Compliance Teams
Wave 3: Leadership + PMs
Wave 4: Sustainment Refresher
10.7.2 Recurring Training
Quarterly refresher training is required for:
Cyber staff
Administrators
Analysts
Annual training shall include updates based on:
New features
Policy changes
Security requirements
Architecture adjustments

10.8 TRAINING EVALUATION & ASSESSMENT
The Contractor shall evaluate training effectiveness using:
Knowledge assessments
Instructor evaluations
User confidence surveys
After-action reviews
Performance analytics from training environments
Findings shall be incorporated into updated materials.

10.9 SUSTAINMENT TRAINING & ONBOARDING
As personnel rotate or roles change, the Contractor shall:
Provide on-demand training
Maintain a training catalog
Ensure updates reflect system changes
Support onboarding of new AF personnel
Training must support long-term operational continuity.
11.0 LOGISTICS, OPERATIONS & SUSTAINMENT REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall implement and maintain a comprehensive sustainment capability supporting continuous, secure, and resilient operations of the Autonomous Logistics Monitoring & Compliance Platform (ALMCP) throughout its lifecycle. Sustainment includes preventative maintenance, corrective maintenance, capacity planning, monitoring, cybersecurity upkeep, and operational support.
All sustainment activities shall align with AFMC sustainment doctrine, AFLCMC digital engineering practices, and relevant DoD cybersecurity policies. Sustainment shall ensure that the platform remains operationally available, secure, performant, and compliant under IL5 constraints.

11.1 SUSTAINMENT STRATEGY
The Contractor shall develop, maintain, and Government-approve a Sustainment Strategy that addresses:
Operational support model
Roles and responsibilities
Organizational interfaces (AF, DLA, contractors, PMO)
Mission-critical dependencies
Preventative maintenance scheduling
Capacity and scalability planning
Performance optimization approach
Supply chain risk mitigation processes
Software lifecycle management
The Strategy shall be updated annually or upon major system changes.

11.2 OPERATIONS & MAINTENANCE (O&M)
The Contractor shall perform or support:
11.2.1 Preventative Maintenance
System health reviews
Patching and updates
Database maintenance
Pipeline optimization
Retention policy enforcement
KMS key rotation checks
11.2.2 Corrective Maintenance
Corrective actions include:
Incident troubleshooting
Bug fixes
Hotfix patch deployment
Rapid recovery after outages
Configuration corrections
Data quality issue resolution
All corrective actions must be logged.
11.2.3 Operational Monitoring
The system shall be monitored for:
CPU, memory, storage
API response times
Ingestion throughput
ML pipeline health
Zero Trust policy drift
Access control anomalies
Data quality degradation
Compliance drift indicators
Log completeness
Monitoring shall be 24×7×365.

11.3 AVAILABILITY & PERFORMANCE SLAs
The Contractor shall meet or exceed the following Service-Level Agreements (SLAs):
11.3.1 Availability
99.9% uptime per month (excluding scheduled maintenance)
11.3.2 Mean Time to Detect (MTTD)
≤ 5 minutes for high-severity faults
≤ 15 minutes for medium-severity faults
11.3.3 Mean Time to Respond (MTTR)
Severity 1: ≤ 30 minutes
Severity 2: ≤ 2 hours
Severity 3: ≤ 8 hours
11.3.4 Recovery Time Objective (RTO)
≤ 60 minutes for critical system outage
11.3.5 Recovery Point Objective (RPO)
≤ 15 minutes for data loss scenarios
11.3.6 Performance Baselines
Dashboard load ≤ 4 seconds
Compliance report generation ≤ 45 seconds
Ingestion latency ≤ 5 seconds per event
AI/ML scoring ≤ 2 seconds per object
Metrics shall be presented in monthly performance reports.

11.4 CONTINUOUS MONITORING (CONMON) OPERATIONS
The Contractor shall operate and maintain a CONMON capability aligned to NIST SP 800-137.
Required monitoring dimensions include:
System health
Cybersecurity posture
Configuration drift
Access events
Compliance score trends
ML anomaly monitoring
Data classification drift
Network segmentation integrity
CONMON outputs include:
Weekly dashboards
Monthly reports
Automated alerts
ATO-related updates

11.5 PATCH MANAGEMENT
The Contractor shall implement a secure patch management process including:
11.5.1 Patch Prioritization
Based on:
Severity
Exploitability
IL5 posture
Operational impact
11.5.2 Patch Testing
All patches must be tested in:
Dev
Test
Security
Pre-Prod
11.5.3 Patch Deployment
Deployment must be:
Zero-downtime when possible
Coordinated with Government
Documented
Logged
11.5.4 Emergency Patches
Emergency security patches must be deployed within:
24 hours (high severity)
72 hours (medium severity)

11.6 CONFIGURATION MANAGEMENT (CM)
The Contractor shall implement CM aligned with:
AFLCMC digital engineering practices
RMF CM controls
Infrastructure-as-Code (IaC) standards
CM tasks include:
Version control
Baseline management
Change approval workflows
Release documentation
Impact assessment
Rollback procedures
Each change requires a security impact review.

11.7 INCIDENT MANAGEMENT
The Contractor shall deliver an Incident Management Plan covering:
Incident logging
Event triage procedures
Notification timeframes
Root cause analysis (RCA)
Resolution and validation
Communication workflows
Severity Definitions
Severity 1: Mission-impacting; immediate response required
Severity 2: High risk but no outage
Severity 3: Minor operational degradation
All Severity 1 incidents must be reported to the Government within 1 hour.

11.8 BACKUP, RESTORE & DISASTER RECOVERY
11.8.1 Backup Requirements
Automated backups every 15 minutes
Multi-AZ encrypted storage
Separation between logical and operational domains
Retention for 30–90 days based on metadata type
11.8.2 Restore Requirements
The Contractor shall:
Validate backups weekly
Perform monthly restore drills
Document results
Address discrepancies
11.8.3 Disaster Recovery
The Contractor shall:
Maintain DR runbooks
Support annual DR exercises
Validate cross-region failover (IL5-approved)
Demonstrate system recovery within SLA parameters

11.9 CAPACITY PLANNING & SCALABILITY
The Contractor shall perform:
Quarterly capacity assessments
Growth forecasting
Stress testing
Recommendation reports
Scalability must support:
5× projected ingestion growth
3× user concurrency growth
10× analytics task growth

11.10 OPERATIONAL DOCUMENTATION
The Contractor shall maintain:
11.10.1 SOP Libraries
Covering:
Ingestion troubleshooting
ML model deployment
Compliance workflows
UI administration
Cybersecurity procedures
11.10.2 Technical Manuals
Including:
Subsystem diagrams
API references
Schema definitions
Configurable parameters
11.10.3 As-Built Documentation
Updated with each release.

11.11 HELP DESK & SUPPORT SERVICES
The Contractor shall provide a Tiered Support Model:
Tier 0 — Self-Service
FAQs
Knowledge base
Tier 1 — User Support
Login issues
Dashboard questions
Tier 2 — Application Support
Workflow errors
Incorrect analytics
Compliance report issues
Tier 3 — Engineering Support
Code-level issues
Database tuning
Pipeline debugging
All support actions must be logged for audit.
12.0 PROGRAM MANAGEMENT REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall implement a comprehensive program management structure that ensures coordinated execution, transparency, risk reduction, cost control, schedule integrity, and alignment with AFLCMC program office expectations. Effective program management is essential to ensuring the Autonomous Logistics Monitoring & Compliance Platform (ALMCP) meets Air Force mission needs, cybersecurity demands, and performance requirements.
All program management activities shall follow AFLCMC standard practices, DoD acquisition guidelines, Agile/DevSecOps methodologies, and the Adaptive Acquisition Framework (AAF) where applicable.

12.1 PROGRAM MANAGEMENT OFFICE (PMO)
The Contractor shall establish a PMO responsible for:
Planning and overseeing contract execution
Maintaining the Integrated Master Schedule (IMS)
Managing risks, issues, and opportunities
Interfacing with the Air Force PMO
Overseeing subcontractors
Managing staffing and personnel rotations
Monitoring performance metrics
Ensuring compliance with contractual requirements
12.1.1 PMO Staffing
The Contractor’s PMO shall include:
Program Manager (PM)
Deputy PM
Technical Lead / Chief Engineer
Cybersecurity Lead
Data Lead
DevSecOps Lead
Test Lead
Configuration Manager
Requirements Manager
Quality Assurance Manager
All PMO personnel shall be U.S. citizens. Personnel in cybersecurity or IL5-sensitive roles must undergo appropriate background checks.

12.2 INTEGRATED MASTER SCHEDULE (IMS)
The Contractor shall develop and maintain a detailed IMS containing:
All major contractual tasks
Dependencies
Critical path identification
Milestones
Deliverable deadlines
Integration timelines
T&E schedules
ATO preparation milestones
Deployment windows
Sustainment cycles
The IMS must:
Use Government-approved formats
Contain >90% resource-loaded tasks
Be updated monthly
Reflect progress using percent-complete methodology
Be traceable to PWS requirements
Government will review IMS during PMRs.

12.3 STATUS REPORTING & COMMUNICATIONS
The Contractor shall provide:
12.3.1 Weekly Status Reports
Containing:
Progress updates
Blockers
Risks and issues
Staffing status
Change requests
Metrics summary
12.3.2 Monthly Program Management Reviews (PMRs)
Covering:
Technical status
Cybersecurity posture
Schedule performance
Budget execution
Risk/issue review
Action item closures
Metrics dashboards
Upcoming milestones
12.3.3 Ad-Hoc Briefings
At Government request, the Contractor shall provide technical, cyber, or programmatic briefings on short notice.

12.4 RISK MANAGEMENT
The Contractor shall implement a formal risk management framework aligned with AFLCMC and DoDI 5000.02 requirements.
12.4.1 Risk Identification
Risks may include:
Technical feasibility
Cybersecurity vulnerabilities
Integration complexity
Data quality issues
ML model performance variance
IL5 compliance risk
Personnel turnover
Vendor dependencies
12.4.2 Risk Analysis
Each risk shall include:
Probability
Impact
Severity rating
Mitigation strategy
Trigger indicators
12.4.3 Risk Mitigation
Mitigation may include:
Prototyping
Increased testing
Alternative design pathways
Additional controls
Contractual action against non-performing subcontractors
12.4.4 Risk Reporting
Risks shall be:
Reviewed weekly
Documented in a risk register
Presented during PMRs
Escalated for Government action when required

12.5 ISSUE MANAGEMENT
The Contractor shall maintain an issue tracking system capturing:
Issue description
Impacted functional areas
Root cause
Ownership
Resolution timelines
Required Government decisions
Closure evidence
Issues older than 30 days require justification.

12.6 CHANGE MANAGEMENT
The Contractor shall implement a Change Management Plan covering:
Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs)
Configuration Change Requests (CCRs)
Documentation updates
Impact analysis on performance, security, and schedule
Versioning and release controls
Government approval thresholds
Changes impacting IL5 security posture require pre-approval from the Government Security Office.

12.7 REQUIREMENTS MANAGEMENT
The Contractor shall:
Maintain a Requirements Traceability Matrix (RTM)
Ensure traceability from SOO → PWS → System Requirements → Test Cases
Document requirement interpretations
Identify gaps and propose clarifications
Validate system delivery against requirements
The RTM shall be updated with each major release.

12.8 CONFIGURATION MANAGEMENT (CM)
CM activities must align with:
AFLCMC CM processes
RMF CM controls (CM-1 to CM-13)
DevSecOps configuration baselines
CM responsibilities include:
Identify and document baselines
Manage version-controlled IaC, microservices, APIs
Ensure reproducible builds
Maintain change logs
Prevent unauthorized configuration changes
Perform quarterly CM audits
A Configuration Control Board (CCB) shall review all changes.

12.9 QUALITY ASSURANCE (QA)
QA processes must ensure:
Compliance with contractual requirements
Adherence to IL5 security controls
Code quality and style consistency
Documentation completeness
Testing coverage thresholds
Release validation before production deployment
The QA Lead shall provide monthly QA reports.

12.10 SUBCONTRACTOR MANAGEMENT
The Contractor shall:
Vet all subcontractors for security compliance
Ensure all subcontractor personnel are U.S. citizens
Restrict subcontractor access to IL5 environments
Oversee subcontractor performance
Report subcontractor issues immediately
The Prime Contractor is wholly responsible for subcontractor actions.

12.11 FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT
The Contractor shall:
Monitor spend rates
Provide monthly burn rate analyses
Forecast financial needs
Align expenditures with IMS tasks
Notify Government of potential overruns or underruns
Maintain transparency in all invoicing

12.12 GOVERNMENT FURNISHED MATERIAL (GFM) & INFORMATION (GFI)
The Contractor shall safeguard:
GFI
Provided architecture diagrams
Sample datasets
Interface documentation
Access credentials
Security templates
Unauthorized disclosure constitutes a significant breach.

12.13 CONTRACTOR-FURNISHED MATERIAL (CFM)
All Contractor-provided:
Tools
Licenses
Cloud components
Container images
CI/CD pipelines
Documentation
must meet IL5 requirements and be Government-assessable.

12.14 MEETING & REVIEW REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall support:
Weekly technical syncs
Bi-weekly cyber reviews
Monthly PMRs
Quarterly strategic reviews
Annual architecture update sessions
The Government reserves the right to schedule additional meetings.

13.0 DELIVERABLES, CDRLs & REPORTING REQUIREMENTS
The Contractor shall provide all deliverables required to design, develop, test, deploy, secure, and sustain the Autonomous Logistics Monitoring & Compliance Platform (ALMCP). Deliverables shall follow the Data Item Descriptions (DIDs) associated with each Contract Data Requirements List (CDRL) entry. All deliverables shall be classified, marked, protected, and transmitted according to IL5 and Air Force cybersecurity rules.
Deliverables are subject to Government approval and shall be stored in Government-designated repositories.

13.1 GENERAL DELIVERABLE REQUIREMENTS
All deliverables shall meet the following criteria:
13.1.1 Quality Requirements
Deliverables must be:
Complete
Accurate
Free of security violations
IL5 compliant
Written in clear technical language
Version-controlled
Formatted according to AFLCMC standards
13.1.2 Delivery Requirements
Deliverables must:
Meet IMS due dates
Include revision histories
Use Government-approved templates (when provided)
Include classification markings and distribution controls
Be accessible to Government personnel via IL5 systems
13.1.3 Acceptance Process
Deliverables are accepted only when:
They meet stated requirements
The Government reviews and signs acceptance
All corrections requested during review are addressed
Associated artifacts (e.g., diagrams, evidence files) are included

13.2 CONTRACT DATA REQUIREMENTS LIST (CDRLs)
Below is a representative set of CDRLs included in the ALMCP program.
(Note: In a real AFLCMC contract, each would map to a DD Form 1423.)

13.2.1 CDRL A001 – Program Management Plan (PMP)

13.2.4 CDRL A004 – System Architecture Document (SAD)

13.2.6 CDRL A006 – Data Management Strategy

13.2.7 CDRL A007 – Test & Evaluation Master Plan (TEMP)

13.2.8 CDRL A008 – Training Materials

13.2.9 CDRL A009 – Deployment Strategy

13.2.11 CDRL A011 – Monthly Status Report (MSR)

13.2.12 CDRL A012 – Compliance Automation Reports

13.2.15 CDRL A015 – Supply Chain & Vendor Risk Assessment Reports

13.3 DELIVERABLE FORMATS
The Contractor shall deliver documents in:
Microsoft Word (.docx)

JSON/XML for machine-readable artifacts
Diagram source formats (.drawio, .vsdx)
SCORM files for CBT
All documents must include:

Version ID
Authoring information
Distribution statements

13.4 REPORTING REQUIREMENTS

Include:
Activities completed
Upcoming activities
Risks/issues

Security events summary
13.4.2 Monthly PMRs
Include:
Detailed technical updates
Cyber posture
ML performance metrics
Compliance summaries

13.4.3 Quarterly Strategic Reviews
Include:

13.5 ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA
Deliverables and capabilities will be accepted when:
13.5.1 Technical Acceptance
The system meets functional requirements

13.5.2 Cybersecurity Acceptance

13.5.3 Data Acceptance

13.5.5 Training Acceptance

13.5.6 Deployment Acceptance
