Government reserves full approval authority.
14.0 GLOSSARY & DEFINITIONS
This section defines key terms used throughout the SOO/PWS. Definitions follow DoD, NIST, and Air Force standard nomenclature.

14.1 DEFINITIONS
Accountability
The requirement to document, audit, and trace all actions performed by users or systems.
AI/ML (Artificial Intelligence / Machine Learning)
Algorithms and models used to detect anomalies, forecast disruptions, classify data, and support decision-making.
Access Control
Mechanisms enforcing who or what can read, write, modify, or transmit data based on identity, attributes, or context.
Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC)
An access control mechanism using attributes (user role, clearance, device, time, classification, etc.) for dynamic authorization.
Audit Log
Immutable record documenting system and user events, including timestamp, actor, and action performed.
Authority to Operate (ATO)
Formal authorization for a system to operate within the DoD environment after assessment of security controls.
Availability
Measured uptime of the system or component within specific performance constraints.
Compliance Automation
The process of automatically mapping system telemetry, evidence, and actions to regulatory or policy controls.
Configuration Baseline
Approved specification of a system’s configuration that may only be changed via a formal process.
Continuous Monitoring
Ongoing assessment of system security posture, configuration drift, user activity, and compliance indicators.
Covered Defense Information (CDI)
Information requiring safeguarding under DFARS 252.204-7012.
Data Lineage
Documentation of the origin, movement, transformation, and storage of data across its lifecycle.
Data Quality
Evaluation of accuracy, completeness, consistency, timeliness, and validity of data.
DevSecOps
Combined development, security, and operations practices utilizing automation, CI/CD pipelines, and integrated security.
Disaster Recovery (DR)
Ability to restore critical functions following disruptive events.
Impact Level 5 (IL5)
DoD cloud classification level for controlled, sensitive unclassified information requiring stringent separation and security controls.
Ingestion Pipeline
Processes responsible for receiving, validating, normalizing, enriching, and classifying incoming data.
Least Privilege
Zero Trust principle limiting users and services to only the permissions absolutely required.
Metadata
Information describing attributes, origin, structure, security, and semantics of data.
Microservice
Self-contained service executing a specific function, independently deployable and scalable.
Provenance
Record capturing the origin and processing history of data to ensure traceability.
Risk Score
Quantitative or semi-quantitative measure representing relative likelihood or impact of mission disruption.
Zero Trust Architecture
An architecture where no implicit trust exists; every request is continuously authenticated and authorized.

15.0 ACRONYMS
Below is an extended acronym list aligned with Air Force and DoD documentation.

16.0 APPENDIX A — QUALITY ASSURANCE SURVEILLANCE PLAN (QASP)
The QASP defines how the Government will monitor, evaluate, and verify Contractor performance.
16.1 PURPOSE
To ensure the Contractor meets all PWS requirements by defining surveillance methods, performance metrics, and acceptable quality levels.

16.2 SURVEILLANCE METHODS
The Government may use one or more of the following:
100% Inspection — Full review of deliverables
Sampling — Review subset of artifacts
Periodic Monitoring — Weekly/monthly review cycles
User Feedback — Analyst/PMO feedback loops
Automated Monitoring — Dashboards, logs, alerts
Surveillance is continuous and may occur without prior notice.

16.3 PERFORMANCE METRICS

17.0 APPENDIX B — REQUIREMENTS TRACEABILITY MATRIX (RTM)
The RTM ensures every requirement traces back to:
SOO objective
PWS requirement
System specification
Test case
Contractor shall maintain the RTM as a living artifact.
Example RTM Format:

18.0 APPENDIX C — ZERO TRUST ARCHITECTURE OVERVIEW
This appendix details ALMCP’s Zero Trust alignment.
Identity Pillar
ICAM integration
CAC/PIV authentication
ABAC rulesets
Network Pillar
Segmentation
mTLS
WAF filtering
Application Pillar
Secure coding
SBOM validation
RASP integration
Data Pillar
Classification enforcement
Encryption in transit/at rest
Attribute-based data access
Analytics Pillar
Behavior analytics
Threat scoring
Drift detection
Automation Pillar
Policy-as-code
Automated remediations
Continuous compliance reporting

19.0 APPENDIX D — PROGRAM PROTECTION & SUPPLY CHAIN SECURITY
19.1 PROGRAM PROTECTION
Contractor must maintain:
Anti-tamper controls
Secure build pipelines
Protect intellectual property
Protect against reverse engineering
19.2 SOFTWARE SUPPLY CHAIN SECURITY
Requirements include:
SBOM for all releases
Signed dependencies
No public registries in production
Continuous scanning of build artifacts
19.3 HARDWARE SUPPLY CHAIN (IF APPLICABLE)
If any hardware is introduced:
Components must be trusted suppliers
No foreign-sourced components without approval
Serialization and tracking must be maintained

20.0 APPENDIX E — DOCUMENT DISTRIBUTION STATEMENT
All documents shall include:
Distribution Statement C:
"Distribution authorized to U.S. Government agencies and their contractors due to administrative or operational use. Other requests shall be referred to the contracting officer."

1.0 Purpose
This guide consolidates supplemental requirements not captured in the PWS but mandatory for ALMCP due to IL5 classification, cybersecurity posture, and AFLCMC digital engineering policies.

2.0 Mandatory Development Constraints
2.1 Coding Standards
The Contractor shall:
Adhere to DoD Enterprise DevSecOps Reference Design
Provide style guides for:
API naming
Microservice boundaries
Logging & telemetry
Pass strict linting with no critical violations
2.2 Documentation Requirements
Every microservice shall have its own As-Built
All diagrams must be provided in .drawio + PDF
All exports marked with Distro Statement C

3.0 Mandatory Security Enhancements
3.1 Zero Trust Enforcement Additions
All service accounts must use short-lived tokens
All API gateway rules shall explicitly define:
Deny-by-default
Allowed actors
Attribute constraints
3.2 Identity Requirements
Contractor must support:
CAC/PIV
ICAM attribute sync
Login anomaly detection

4.0 Government Rights in Data / IP Clauses
You may include:
DFARS 252.227-7013 Rights in Technical Data
DFARS 252.227-7014 Rights in Noncommercial Computer Software
DFARS 252.227-7025 Limitations on Use
All custom code delivered must include unlimited rights for DoD operational use.

5.0 Environmental & Hosting Requirements
Multi-AZ architecture mandatory
All autoscaling events must be logged
Air-gapped migration pipeline required
Backup test restores must succeed monthly

The QASP describes how the Government will evaluate Contractor performance for ALMCP.
It establishes:
Surveillance methods
Performance standards
Acceptable quality levels
Metrics and thresholds
It is NOT direction to the Contractor — it is a Government oversight tool.

2.0 SURVEILLANCE APPROACH

3.0 SURVEILLANCE METHODS
Periodic Sampling – weekly review
100% Inspection – for security reports
User Feedback – PMO + analyst sessions
Automated Dashboards – ingestion, Zero Trust metrics, classification drift

docs.id: e8acd3dd-1b4c-43da-b908-4ec694b5816d-1765154121051-TEST_#1_DEPARTMENT OF THE AIR FORCE_REQUIREMENTS SUPPLEMENT & CLAUSE ADDENDUM.docx
docs.name: TEST_#1_DEPARTMENT OF THE AIR FORCE_REQUIREMENTS SUPPLEMENT & CLAUSE ADDENDUM.docx
docs.content:
1.0 PURPOSE
This Requirements Supplement provides additional mandatory technical, cybersecurity, and programmatic requirements that support the ALMCP SOO/PWS.
These requirements carry the weight of the PWS and shall be flowed down into all subcontractor agreements.

2.0 ADDITIONAL TECHNICAL REQUIREMENTS
2.1 System Modularity Requirements
The Contractor shall ensure the ALMCP system is architected such that:
Microservices may be replaced without full-system outage
Data services are isolated into separate enclaves (processing, analytics, compliance, metadata)
Each subsystem has a defined ICD and versioning strategy
No module contains “monolithic” logic exceeding 2,500 LoC
2.2 Data Isolation Requirements
CLI-S datasets MUST NOT co-mingle with CLI-M datasets
All data flows shall implement classification-aware routing
All exports shall undergo automated classification checks

3.0 ADDITIONAL CYBERSECURITY REQUIREMENTS
3.1 Mandatory Safeguards
The Contractor shall:
Perform weekly dependency SBOM comparison
Implement “breakglass” privileged access controls with full audit logs
Demonstrate RASP (Runtime Application Self-Protection) coverage for API layers
Provide an annual insider threat risk assessment
3.2 Prohibited Actions (All IL5 Environments)
No use of GitHub-hosted public CI runners
No downloading container images from Docker Hub
No outbound egress to non-GovCloud resources

4.0 ADDITIONAL PROGRAMMATIC REQUIREMENTS
4.1 Sprint & DevSecOps Cadence
The Contractor shall:
Provide bi-weekly sprint demos in IL5 test environment
Release monthly minor versions & quarterly major versions
Maintain a release backlog with Government visibility
4.2 Decision Trails & Architectural Rigor
Every architectural decision must include:
Problem statement
Alternatives considered
Security and IL5 impacts
Cost/schedule implications
All decisions must be traceable.

5.0 MANDATORY FEDERAL/DFARS CLAUSES (SUPPLEMENTAL)
The following shall be incorporated into the contract:
DFARS 252.204-7012 Safeguarding CDI
DFARS 252.204-7024 Notice on the Use of DoD Cloud Computing
DFARS 252.239-7009 Representation of Use of Cloud Computing
DFARS 252.239-7010 Cloud Computing Services
FAR 52.239-1 Privacy & Security Safeguards
DFARS 252.204-7021 CMMC Level 2
The Contractor shall provide compliance evidence quarterly.

ALMCP Requirements Traceability Matrix (RTM)
Version 1.0 — January 2025

aiSummary:
OVERVIEW
The Department of the Air Force (DAF) seeks to acquire, deploy, secure, and sustain the Autonomous Logistics Monitoring & Compliance Platform (ALMCP), a unified capability enhancing supply chain intelligence, strengthening cyber posture, and enabling senior leadership to take timely, risk-informed actions. The ALMCP will ingest and normalize multi-source logistics data, automate compliance against NIST, DFARS, and Air Force policies, provide AI-assisted anomaly detection and risk scoring, enhance visibility across supply chain nodes, support IL5 mission systems and enclave requirements, and enable readiness-focused decision making. The contractor will deliver comprehensive logistics monitoring and compliance capabilities, including IL5 cloud-native logistics analytics, Zero Trust microservices, ETL pipelines, compliance automation, integrations with D035A, IMDS, GO81, and other relevant systems, sustainment, training, and program management.

MISSION & OBJECTIVE
- Provide a unified capability for supply chain intelligence, cyber posture enhancement, and readiness-focused decision making.
- Acquire, deploy, secure, and sustain the Autonomous Logistics Monitoring & Compliance Platform (ALMCP).

SCOPE OF WORK
- Ingest and normalize multi-source logistics data.
- Automate compliance against NIST, DFARS, and Air Force policies.
- Provide AI-assisted anomaly detection and risk scoring.
- Enhance visibility across supply chain nodes.
- Support IL5 mission systems and enclave requirements.
- Enable readiness-focused decision making.

ARCHITECTURE & TECH APPROACH
- Develop a cloud-native logistics analytics platform utilizing IL5 GovCloud environment.
- Implement Zero Trust microservices architecture for enhanced security and compliance.
- Establish ETL pipelines for data integration and normalization.
- Integrate with relevant systems, including D035A, IMDS, GO81.

SECURITY, COMPLIANCE & HOSTING CONSTRAINTS
- Ensure NIST 800-171, DFARS 7012, and internal AF security controls compliance.
- Implement Zero Trust architecture to mitigate adversarial cyber operations targeting logistics systems.
- Comply with IL5 mission system and enclave requirements for data storage and processing.

DATA SCOPE & AUTHORIZATION BOUNDARY
- Ingest multi-source logistics data from legacy systems (D035A, IMDS, GO81).
- Normalize and process data within the contractor's environment in IL5 GovCloud.
- Contractor environment enters the Government boundary for compliance automation and AI-assisted anomaly detection.

ENDPOINTS / DEVICE EXPECTATIONS
- No clear indication of GFE or VDI requirements; endpoint requirements must be clarified.

CONTRACT-SPECIFIC RISKS
- Inconsistent data accuracy and provenance across organizations and contract vehicles.
- Manual compliance overhead for NIST, DFARS, and internal AF security controls.
- Growing threat environment with adversarial cyber operations targeting logistics systems.

GAPS / QUESTIONS FOR THE GOVERNMENT
- Clarify endpoint requirements for contractors.
- Define data lineage, quality scoring, validation, and provenance tracking across organizations and contract vehicles.

RECOMMENDED INTERNAL ACTIONS
- Develop a detailed data management plan to address inconsistent accuracy and provenance.
- Establish clear compliance automation procedures for NIST, DFARS, and internal AF security controls.
- Enhance contractor training on Zero Trust architecture and IL5 mission system requirements.

docSummaries.e8acd3dd-1b4c-43da-b908-4ec694b5816d-176:
Structured Summary

### OBJECTIVE
The Department of the Air Force (DAF) aims to acquire a comprehensive Autonomous Logistics Monitoring & Compliance Platform (ALMCP) that enhances supply chain intelligence, strengthens cyber posture, and enables senior leadership to take timely, risk-informed actions.

### SCOPE
The Contractor shall deliver system architecture, secure software design, enclave integration, data ingestion + ETL pipelines, analytics layer, compliance engine, dashboards, testing + evaluation, training, IL5 sustainment, and a full ATO package.

### KEY REQUIREMENTS

1. Compliance Automation: Automated control mapping, evidence extraction, and assessment against NIST 800-171, NIST 800-53 Rev 5, DFARS 252.204-7012, AF cybersecurity policies, Cloud SRG IL5.
2. Predictive Intelligence: ML-enhanced risk scoring for vendor reliability, part availability, counterfeit indicators, supply chain manipulation, cyber-logistics compromise.
3. IL5 Aligned Security Posture: A Zero Trust, enclave-compliant system with end-to-end encryption, auditability, and cyber hardening.

### KEY RISKS

1. Cybersecurity Risks: Adversaries targeting logistics nodes, contractor manufacturing facilities, and unclassified-but-sensitive systems supporting readiness.
2. Data Classification: Handling of CUI/PII/SBU/CTI data within the ALMCP system.
3. Compliance with NIST SP 800-171 and DFARS 252.204-7012: Ensuring compliance with these regulations is a critical requirement.

### GAPS AND AMBIGUITIES

1. The contract text does not explicitly state whether the Contractor shall obtain or maintain any specific certifications (e.g., CMMC).
2. There are multiple references to "AI-assisted" and "ML-enhanced" capabilities, but it is unclear what specific AI/ML tools or solutions will be used.

### RECOMMENDED NEXT STEPS

1. Clarify the requirement for obtaining or maintaining CMMC certification.
2. Specify the AI/ML tools or solutions to be used for predictive intelligence and compliance automation.
3. Ensure that the Contractor understands the scope of data classification requirements and handling procedures for CUI/PII/SBU/CTI data within the ALMCP system.

Note: This summary focuses on the key aspects related to DFARS, NIST 800-171, and cybersecurity. Other sections of the contract may require additional analysis or clarification.
